title: Build Word2Vec Style Machine Learning Model to predict Images using Session Co-occurrence
snippet:
My website:
I run a search engine for images where users can also save images to collections. My website is identical to Pinterest.com.

Currently I have a Co-Occurrence Word2Vec based model that is based on the Image Id's found within the Collection: `[image_id_5, image_id_2, image_id_16, ...]. This list would contain all the ids within the collection and each collection would be grouped into a parent list—it's the same way you train Word2Vec normally (document -> sentence (collection_id) -> word (image_id).

Project:
When a user views an image, there is a feed of images shown below and my goal is to improve those results. To do this, I'm looking to utilize click tracking data per session and Collection Co-Occurrence data to build a retrainable model.

Collection Co-occurrence images are images that have also been saved to the same collection as the query image. These usually are always similar to the query image. 

Problem: 
The problem with my Collection Co-occurrence model is that the relatedness of the items are too narrow. By utilizing a trained model on both the Co-occurrence data AND Image_ids that are viewed within a user's session, there is a strong potential to improve the results.

Pinterest has accomplished this by using a user’s browsing session on Pinterest as the training data. Imagine each user session is a sentence with Image Ids as words. Basically if in a browsing session you visit pins A then B then C then D, it trains the network such that given A it predicts B, etc. This also helps capture semantic similarity. 

Here is a paper about how they accomplished it: 
https://medium.com/the-graph/applying-deep-learning-to-related-pins-a6fee3c92f5e
https://arxiv.org/pdf/1702.07969.pdf
https://medium.com/pinterest-engineering/an-update-on-pixie-pinterests-recommendation-system-6f273f737e1b

Deliverables:
I'm looking at creating a simplified version of this using the word2vec method, session data, biased random walks. 

Deliverables:
- Python 3.6

- Models would be trained on a CPU server and we're only dealing with 1 million images right now.

title: NIST Handwriting recognition to CoreML
snippet:
Are you interested in a unique ML challenge, then you will love this project.

Apple iOS has made huge advancements with its CoreML model. And while it can reasonably detect handwriting digits using the MNIST dataset, there is no model available for handwriting character recognition. 

So we need one built.

Specifically, using the NIST Special 19 dataset (https://www.nist.gov/srd/nist-special-database-19) and/or the IAM Handwriting dataset (https://www.kaggle.com/tejasreddy/iam-handwriting-top50), we want to create a CoreML model that can be used in an iOS application. 

This project is inspired by the work for Japanese character recognition (https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/build-a-handwriting-recognizer-ship-it-to-app-store-fcce24205b4b/) and TejasReddy9 (https://github.com/TejasReddy9/handwriting_cnn)

Hence this project is fairly straight-forward; create the most accurate COREML module for English handwriting characters that we can integrate into our XCode project.

title: Algorithm and Python Expert for Garment sizing recommendation
snippet:
We are a garment sizing recommendation software company based in Estonia and London. Our software is used by fashion retailers to give their customers a better decision on what size to purchase. Right now the app works purely using past shopper data and sizing feedback, no size charts required. 

We do not use any machine learning or advanced algorithms to make the sizing predictions, and therefore the current build has various weaknesses and can cause inaccuracies. We also do not utilise any external datasets. 
To improve the software and utilize machine learning to make more precise sizing recommendations, we are seeking a data scientist with python experience and general experience in solving similar situations to our use-case. 

To summarise what we do have and what we want:

We HAVE:
- Gender, height, weight, body shape, fit preference, age -  from previous customers
- Fit feedback on if the product they purchased fitted them or not. 

We DON'T have:
- Use of public datasets, such as:
https://www.kaggle.com/rmisra/clothing-fit-dataset-for-size-recommendation
https://github.com/rishabhmisra/Product-Catalog-Size-Recommendation-Framework

At the moment we are relying only on our own data from the specific retailers existing customer base. This means that we cannot give predictions on size until the product has a specific number of purchases from customers who provided their body data. We would like to combine datasets such as this one above in order to provide recommendations when we don't yet have purchase data. The question is, how can we utilise this public dataset in our use-case and combine it with our brand specific purchase data?

- Currently fit feedback has no impact on recommendations. The way we are generating recommendations is based solely on PHP now (finding close data within a specific height/weight range), not an ML model. 

- We do not have a model that can take garment measurements and predict sizing based solely on the garment measurements. See this article
https://tylerburleigh.com/blog/predicting-t-shirt-size-from-height-and-weight/

I would like to know if it is a viable option to create recommendations based on garment measurements provided by a specific retailer. OR should we stick to utilising clothing fit datasets like mentioned further up? What is the best way of cold starting a product size predictions? If a product has no purchase data, how should we generate recommendations - using the public purchase dataset, or by requesting garment measurements from the brand and utilising them in a model?

--------

We already had an ML model made by a data scientist using random forests and the problem we encounted is that if there was one row in the database where a customer provided fit feedback stating a product fitted them, it would generate a recommendation of 100% certainty that the new visitor should choose this size. It did not consider other close values. If there was only one entry for someone of the same height, weight with fit feedback of 'fitted' then ignoring other data. I understand this is how most algorithms work, but how to we solve this?

Before we hired this data scientist we heard about using recommendation models like LightFM, but in the end assumed this would not be suitable for our use case. Maybe we do infact need to use a similar model to this. 

-----

You will be responsible for reviewing our current process, reviewing and planning implementation of improved algorithm, utilising public datasets combined with our own data and building a new solution. Your knowledge and work will be fundamental to the improvement of our software so it is vital that we hire something who is highly talented with great mathematical skill. 

Your application should be integrated with our PHP application, most likely through an API. You should be able to support our developer on integrating your system.

title: Python developer needed for Listrak integration using REST
snippet:
We're looking for an experienced Python developer to take over an API project underway. The internal resource assigned to the project no longer has availability to complete this on time, but will remain as the main contact for the project.

The project involves interfacing with a SQL Server database to extract information, in this case the DB is Microsoft NAV so relevant experience a huge plus. The Python program will then compile the necessary information from the database in one of a number of potential ways, manipulate it, and send it via REST API to the email marketing platform Listrak. There may also be other online resources that need pulled in to fully compile the information sent via API.

The project is well underway and hosted on Bitbucket. The work of establishing a connection to the Listrak API by securing an Oauth2 token has already been done (using Python modules requests and requests-oauthlib). What remains is pulling in a secondary online source to round out the information pulled from the NAV database, much of which is also already complete.

The largest pure Python issue to tackle is pulling the necessary information from the data sources and sending it in the proper format to Listrak via API. A knowledgeable and well-versed contact will be able to assist and answer questions 24/7 so this should be a pretty straight forward project that could lead to much more.

Also to be done would be setting up the method by which database information is pulled and refreshed . There are several possible ways to do this and it might not necessarily be done with Python. Experience with MS NAV may allow some interface to that system with web services that would make things safe, secure, and easy.. This specific portion may not end up being done with Python. This can be discussed.

snippet:
We have a really simple Flask app that we basically use as "example code" in our product.  This app is essentially a simple issue tracker app (like JIRA) - you can register/login, see a list of bugs, create new bugs, see bug details, and see user details.  The app itself has 8 different vulnerabilities that I've outlined in our documentation (see attached README).

 - The vulnerabilities will be dependent on the framework used, so they should match up as closely as possible with what could happen in the language of the app (rather than just copying exactly what we did in Python)

There are additional applications with a similar format we can do after if this first project goes well.

title: Complete Marketing Plan for B2C Mobile App
snippet:
We're an education technology startup on the app store. We are a market place for college students to list and rent notes from each other. We also help college students finish their homework assignments. 
We are currently looking for someone to put together a marketing plan, there will be more work as we test out your plan. 

Must be experienced in excel, if you can analyze data using python or R that's a big plus and I will have a lot more work for you. 

You will have access to me for any questions. 

Heres what the plan will consist of: 

1. Market research. Research is the backbone of the marketing plan. Your local library is a great place to start, offering reports like Standard & Poors or IBISWorld. Some library cards even allow access to online services from home. Identify consumer buying habits in the industry, market size, market growth or decline, and any current trends.

2. Target market. A well-designed target market description identifies your most likely buyers. In addition, you should discuss at least two or three levels of segmentation. A language tutoring business might target both students and foreign-born employees who want to improve their English.

3. Positioning. What is the perception of your brand in the marketplace? For example, if your restaurant sells burgers, do customers see you as the place to go for gluten-free or healthy options or the place to go if you’ve got an appetite for a double cheeseburger? The difference in how the target market sees you is your positioning. Develop compelling branding and marketing messages that clearly communicate how you want to be perceived.

4. Competitive analysis. You need to know who your competitors are and how your products and services are different. What is the price point at which your competitors are selling, and what segment of the market are they aiming to reach? Knowing the ins and outs of your competitors will help you better position your business and stand out from the competition.

5. Market strategy. Your marketing strategy is your path to sales goals. Ask yourself “How will I find and attract my most likely buyers?” This is the core of what the strategy should explain. It should look at the entire marketplace and then break down specific tactics including such as events, direct mail, email, social media, content strategy, street teams, couponing, webinars, seminars, partnerships, and other activities that will help you gain access to customers.

6. Budget. Develop a month-by-month schedule of what you plan to spend on marketing. Also include a “red light” decision point. For each activity, establish a metric that tells you to stop if it’s not generating sufficient return on investment (ROI).

7. Metrics. Track your marketing success with Google Analytics for website conversions and a simple Excel sheet to compare your budget against the actual ROI. Test programs over the course of a 30- to 60-day period, and evaluate the results. Repeat any programs that are delivering sales or sign-ups to your email list, and get rid of anything that’s not.

title: Developer to resolve issues with Python CloudCode in a Firebase project

+The App
The app we've created allows people to track activities on their Apple Watch and have them automatically sync to Firebase and then saved within Firebase Firestore. We track the calories in these activities and then total it up with their friends to work towards weekly goals. If they hit the goal they're rewarded.

With the Cron task, every 5 minutes it goes through every team saved within Firestore and performs a number of tasks including:
- Recalculation of the total calories for that week.
- Checking if the goal has been achieved and notify everyone
- Checking if the timer has expired and notifying everyone.
- Etc 
Now that we've been running for a few weeks this task is taking 80 seconds to complete rather than the 1-2 seconds it did when we were in Beta. Currently it parses EVERY challenge, regardless of when it started so we need better queries added to the cron to bring this back down to 1-2 seconds (i.e. only look at active challenges)

+New cloud function.

- Create a new Firestore document in each of the challenges they're part of.  
- Recalculate the total for the challenges the user is part of. 
- Run the Cron (listed above) to check if the challenge has been completed and action it accordingly. This includes sending push notifications, setting values in the challenge object.

title: Developer needed to create a minor POC on a blockchain-enabled drug traceability solution
snippet:
**Job Description**: A developer is needed to come up with a product called Medikisha Dawa, a pharmaceutical supply chain solution that focuses on delivering a blockchain enabled drug traceability solution for manufacturers. 

**Scope of Work**: The solution focuses on a typical medicine manufacturer's supply chain.

**Users**: Manufacturer, Wholesaler,Retailer and Consumer.

**Detailed Description of Solution**:
The blockchain enabled drug traceability solution focuses on a single manufacturer’s use case. The manufacturer has clients who consist of wholesalers and retailers. The wholesalers and retailers are registered to the blockchain by the manufacturer. Once the registration of the actors is done, the wholesaler is assigned a unit of medicine by the manufacturer. The wholesaler later on transfers the same unit of medicine to the retailer. The transfer of units of medicine is registered in the blockchain.
Once the retailer is in receipt of the unit of medicine from the wholesaler, the customer on time of purchase is able to know the source of the drug by scanning the bar code/QR code on the medicine’s casing. The information displayed will relay the handlers of the drug down the supply chain. In the event of rogue drugs, the customer is prompted to report the illegitimate drug.

**Main Objective**: 
The main objective of the job is to come up with a solution that consists of a web app enabled front end that runs its business logic/transactions on a blockchain environment (preferably Hyperledger Sawtooth Lake). The solution should enable the end user (consumer) to be able to trace the origin of the drug once they scan a QR/Bar Code at the time of purchase of the drug. 

NB: Interested freelancers should respond with a detailed description of the Technical Approach they will use.

**Specific Proposal Deliverables for potential respondents**:
1.  System Design for the proposed solution (Solution Architecture, System Diagrams etc)
2. Operations Design: Describe the working of the proposed solution end to end.
3. Outlay the technical specification of the potential solution clearly outlining: the implementation environment, the technical and user requirements.

NB: The system will be an online system, you are advised to suggest affordable potential server spaces that you might host the blockchain and the web application in your technical proposal. (We will foot the cost of hosting). Pricing should be reasonable.

**Technical Skills Required**:
1.  Excellent programming skills: Knowledge of various programming languages, such as C++, Java, and Python will be fundamental. 
2.  Experience with cryptography and blockchain protocols specifically Hyperledger Technologies will be helpful.
3.  Prior experience in developing web applications is required.
4.  Experience working with open-source projects will be an added advantage.
5.  Familiarity with P2P networks
6.  Knowledge on the working of a typical pharmaceutical supply chain.

*Other Desired Skills Required**:
1.  Strong analytical abilities.
2.  Must have effective communication skills.
3.  Realistic and Honest
4.  Believe in Blockchain Technologies!!

snippet:
We are looking for an experienced DevOps specialist with significant experience in PSQL / MySQL, Mongo / SOLR setup to propose an architecture for a data intensive process. We are looking for people having experience having built systems capable of injecting 10TB+ daily. 
All to be hosted on AWS (although we are open to using rented servers).

Requirements:
A python process will preprocess and import XML files multiple times per day. The size of these files can be between 50MB and 10GB. The size of each document is between 10-50KB and has between 15 and 30 fields, text.
The system must be capable of importing files once per hour and there are about 20-30 files in total. In general, we expect the total volume of all XML-Files that have to be imported and updated once per hour to be around 100GB. The total number of unique documents thus varies between 10 and 50 million. 
Once the import is completed, the documents have to be synched to an internal database, that is used by our web application. Our web application receives about 100K requests/day for these documents and is using Django Rest as backend and React as front-end to serve these documents.
All documents have to be synched in parallel to a SOLR Cluster that is being used for the search functionality of the front-end application. The SOLR cluster will receive between 5 and 10 million requests per day.

A more detailed data flow will be provided during the interview.

Our current tech stack is MongoDB, PSQL, SOLR, Python and Django Rest for Backend.

Proposal for auto scaling/autohealing if needed
Cost estimate to confirm budget expectations
